content.description: Start on the right side of the boulder under the "roof". There is an obvious right, slanted foot hold. Start with a right sort of drop knee and a small, left, crimpy foot hold. There are a lot of small hand crimps as you follow the roof left and up. There is one good hand along the top of the roof, although it is not fully necessary to use this. As the roof becomes vertical, the hand holds and foot holds become very easy. I rated this based off the awkward positions you need to start in and the step through move you need to make coming off the start.
content.protection: A crashpad would be recommended, but there is a pretty good landing area.
content.location: This is an obvious boulder on the Beaver Loop Trail near the end that overlooks the river. Walk around either side towards the river, and you will see some great features on the boulder. There is an obvious "roof"-like structure. Start nearest to the bottom of this roof.

content.description: In the middle of the boulder, there is a distinct route that goes right up the middle. It meets with the top of the "roof". This route is just a little difficult for beginners as it is very crimpy. I would recommend starting on this route before the "righteous roof". You will see the topout and be more comfortable after getting through the crux of Righteous Roof.
content.location: In the middle of the boulder, there is a crimp to hold with your right hand. Use a small sloper for your right foot, step your left foot up to the obvious foot hold, or plant on the sloper below. Get your left hand up on a crimp (once you have this you can have fun and put weight on left foot and swing).

content.description: There are a ton of small boulders around, mostly along Pine Point Loop.
